contextId.information: The word "it" refers to the instructions that the writer gives in the previous verse. The full meaning of this can be made clear. The word "flesh" represents the whole body. AT: "If you do this, it will be healing for your body" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: It will be healing to your flesh

contextId.information: In ancient thought, water existed under the earth. This phrase refers to Yahweh causing that water to come out of the earth and make the oceans and rivers exist. AT: "he caused the rivers to flow" or "he caused the oceans to exist" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It is implied that he is not to choose to imitate the actions of the violent person. AT: "Do not ... choose to imitate any of his ways" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Do not ... choose any of his ways

contextId.information: This refers to the time when the writer was a child still living under his father's care. AT: "When I was still a boy learning from my father" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: When I was a son of my father

contextId.information: Implied here is that your promise and the circumstances forced you to save up your money. AT: "had to save up some of your money" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

This can be stated as a new sentence to make clear that this is a result of being lazy. AT: "If you continue to be lazy, your poverty will come" or "While you sleep, poverty will come" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This seems to imply that the young man took very little time to think about what he should do. AT: "He quickly decided to go after her" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This passage implies that a hunter has trapped the deer in order to shoot it with arrows. AT: "until a hunter shoots it in its most important part" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: until an arrow pierces through its liver

contextId.information: Yahweh requires justice and fairness when doing business. Dishonest people used heavier or lighter weights in their scales in order to gain more when buying or selling. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

It is implied that this man lies to his neighbor in order to get his neighbor to join him in violent actions. AT: "A man of violence entices his neighbor" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: A man of violence lies to his neighbor

contextId.information: This refers to how gold and silver are refined. A metal is refined by heating it to a high temperature so that it melts and the impurities may be removed. AT: "The crucible is used to refine silver and the furnace is used to refine gold" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: The crucible is for silver and the furnace is for gold

contextId.information: This refers to the way he speaks. AT: "speaks with few words" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This refers to people trying to do something without the knowledge for how to correctly do it. AT: "to work hard without knowing what you are doing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

This means that a person who is wealthy will have many friends because wealth attracts people. The full meaning of this can be made clear. AT: "Those who are wealthy easily find many friends" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

This refers to while the child is young and will still accept discipline and instruction. The full meaning of this can be made clear. AT: "while he is young" or "while he can still be taught" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

When lending money, the lender would take something from the borrower, such as a garment, as a guarantee of repayment. He would return it after the money was repaid. If the borrower was too poor, someone else could give something to the lender as a guarantee for him. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. AT: "Take a garment as security from the one who guarantees that what a stranger has borrowed will be paid back"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Take a garment of one who has put up security for a stranger

contextId.information: This refers to a person receiving his inheritance before he is supposed to receive it. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear.  AT: "before the right time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Houses in those days had flat roofs. Ancient Israelites spent much time on their roofs, where it was often cooler than inside the house, and sometimes people would build a shelter large enough for a person to sleep in on one corner of the roof. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Houses in those days had flat roofs. Ancient Israelites spent much time on their roofs, where it was often cooler than inside the house, and sometimes people would build a shelter large enough for a person to sleep in on one corner of the roof. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

In order to throw a stone very far, people put it into a sling and swing the sling so that the stone will fly from it very quickly. The result of tying a stone in a sling can be stated clearly. AT: "tying a stone in a sling so that it cannot be thrown" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: tying a stone in a sling

contextId.information: The implied information is that the dog will get angry and bite the person. AT: "Like a person who angers a dog by grabbing its ears" or "Like a person who grabs a dog's ears and is bitten by the dog" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Like one who takes hold of the ears of a dog

contextId.information: It is implied that the person digs the pit as a trap so that someone will fall into it. AT: "Whoever digs a pit to trap someone will fall into it" or "If someone digs a pit in order to trap someone, the one who dug it will fall into it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Whoever digs a pit will fall into it

contextId.information: This is a warning not to brag about what you expect to happen tomorrow. This can be stated clearly. AT: "Do not speak proudly about your plans for tomorrow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

If the borrower was too poor, someone else could give something to the lender as a guarantee for him. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:pro:20:15|20:16]]. AT: "Take a garment as security from the one who guarantees that what a stranger has borrowed will be paid back " (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Take a garment of one who has put up security for a stranger
